mechanoreception.notes: Sea anemones in general possess mechanoreceptors, enabling them to detect physical contact and water movement. This is inferred as a common trait for Actiniidae given their position as the largest family of sea anemones.

chemoreception.notes: Sea anemones use chemoreception to detect food and potential threats. This is inferred to be a common trait, allowing them to capture prey and respond to chemical cues in their environment.

photoreception.notes: The presence or absence of photoreception in Actiniidae is unknown based on provided context. Further research is needed to determine if any members of this family possess light-sensitive structures.
